review_title: Mostly a great organisation, but pockets of toxicity
pros: Brilliant organisation mission - a rewarding place to work. Many fantastic staff. Hybrid working.
cons: Institutional racism, but which they are trying to address. Pockets of toxicity. I decided to leave after 6 months due to mistreatment by my line manager. Within the same small team, two other staff left after just 2 - 3 months in position. One of those was the third person they'd had in that post over about half a year, as none stayed long. There were certain posts in several departments that I was aware of where they'd keep recruiting people who'd then quit within a few months, only for the same thing to happen with the next person recruited, over and over again. For people invited to interview at Wellcome, I'd recommend considering asking how many people have been in the post over the previous 12 months and ideally, speaking with staff in that team to get a sense of the working environment.

Org has just restructured and is reeling from the impact of that - despite the fact that restructuring process took over 18 months, the transition was very chaotic and staff left in the organisation have been left to pick up the pieces. pros: Its a charity, if you buy the various excuses/smokescreens for the unethical behaviour then it is easy to convince yourself that you are doing good and you can pat yourself on the back about it.
cons:
- Like many charities it is part of a vicious cycle. It gets its money from companies that do substantial social/economic/environmental harm, then spends a pittance trying to undo some of these. Largly by throwing money into the pockets of the golden triangle to fill up slush funds. 
- The new strategy is about the vanity of the current director more than anything else, and it is likely the new strategy was implemented in the way it was so as to hide the white elephants that were the priority areas (which are literally the new priorities), these were vanity projects that funnelled money into blackholes (mostly the directors friends) and achieved nothing. The most urgent health problem facing people is cardiometabolic disease, by a very very very large margin so the basis of the strategy is not even true. 
- Pay is poor unless you are in with the boys and working culture mixes the worst of academic (hierarchical, bullying and operationally incompetent) with the worst of corporate (obligatory useless corporate nonsense and embracing "diversity" but only as long as you are of a certain type)
- Wellcome is intent on using its "voice" i,e. lobbying for the things it wants, but dosnt seem to realise that if you hold large sums of money in something then lobby for something that will benifit you financially this is a blatant conflict of interest, no matter how noble the intention . In short Wellcomes determination to influence governments is often done in a highly unethical way. (as was pointed out in the BMJ recently, which pretty much forced the director to resign from SAGE).

I have worked for many companies, including some big corporate machines that are known for treating staff badly but nothing comes close to Wellcome, primarily becuase management there seem to firmly believe that they can do no harm.

pros:
Great facilities 
Two subsidised canteens
Some interesting people to work with
cons:
Elitist culture- it’s all very Oxford and Cambridge. If you don’t fit into that mould you are going to be looked down upon by a lot of people. 

Lack of diversity- there is very little diversity. The only team with any real mix of people are the catering and housekeeping teams. There is a diversity and inclusion team but it’s made up of white, university educated female staff under the age of 35.
  
In their own little bubble- there seems to be a tendency to live in their own little bubble and not pay attention to the outside world works.

HR is very inefficient- despite being a rather large team, processes seem very disjointed and inefficient and seem a bit clueless about what goes on in the organisation.
   
Rather spoiled culture- WT is an organisation that exists to tackle major health issues around the world, from epidemics to affordable dengue vaccinations. Yet staff have little or no awareness (or interest) in what is going on. In turn, there is a massive focus on whatever new tea brand is provided, or a massive project to introduce new hand dryers in the bathrooms. The organisation is cash rich, but still, the organisation should live and breathe a culture of using it’s money for the right causes and those who need it the most.
